Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Microliths and the Development of Cultural Complexity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
What was it that made Homo sapiens such a successful species and the sole remaining hominin on the landscape? What enabled it to colonize the entire world and survive in novel or extreme environments? Some researchers argue the development of a new kind of technology, called "microliths," was a key adaptive strategy in the success and global spread. Benefits of these small tools are argued to include more efficient conversion of raw materials into usable stone tools, creation of innovative and diverse tools, and have been linked with the use of composite tools. Composite tools combine multiple components and are often linked to the spread of mechanically assisted projectile technology and hunting weapons. The appearance and spread of microliths is suggested to be part of a global trend of technological reorganization during the late Pleistocene. However, these associations, and even the definition of "microliths," are problematic. Definitions tend to be contextual and oscillate between broad considerations of any intentionally produced small flake and specific manifestations of small tools. This has complicated understanding of the development, spread, and potential benefits of what is considered a pivotal technological innovation of modern humans. Rather than focusing on a typological definition of microliths, researchers must systematically address how small tools were made. By focusing on the technological system used to produce small tools in different contexts, one can understand how each system varied and whether technological systems for small tool production were convergent solutions that were reinvented or cultural knowledge transmitted within and between groups. This has implications for population structure and interconnectedness during the late Pleistocene. This project will foster international collaborations and provide opportunities for mentorship and training of student participants, including first-generation students, minorities, women, and students with disabilities to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research.

This doctoral dissertation project examines decisions related to systems of provisioning, transport, and the use of composite tools and projectile technology and how these affected the form and systems of production of small tool technologies during the late Pleistocene. The archaeological record during the late Pleistocene has provided early evidence for behavioral changes in modern humans and has been vital to our understanding of the origin and evolution of the species. The researcher will employ technological analysis of stone tool assemblages and experimental archaeology to understand how systems of raw material provisioning and transport influence on technological organization and individual systems of small tool production during the late Pleistocene. Results from this project will contribute to examination of the costs and benefits of different strategies for composite tool manufacture and to provide an independent line of evidence to evaluate the development and spread of projectile weaponry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examined the production of small stone tools, often called “microliths,” during the late Pleistocene in southern Africa. The appearance and spread of small stone tools have been suggested to be part of a global trend of technological reorganization, linked with the development of projectile technology and hunting weapons. However, this association is not as straightforward as it seems. The way researchers define “microliths” varies depending on the time and place, and definitions of the term of include multiple classes of stone tools that are not necessarily comparable to one another. The only consistent component of these definitions is the presence of intentionally produced small stone tools in an assemblage. I analyzed lithic assemblages from two of the earliest technologies to be described as “microlithic,” the Howiesons Poort (~65-58 thousand years ago) and Robberg (~26-12 thousand years ago), but instead of focusing on one or more size-based definitions I focused on identifying when production systems specific to small stone tools were first implemented. The development of production systems specific small stone tools indicates their increasing importance within the toolkit of and to the people producing them. I showed that the current focus on broad classes of lithic artifacts and arbitrary size cutoffs masks the full range of small stone tool production in the late Pleistocene, when these technologies began to emerge. While arguments of projectile use have been made for both technologies, they are for different reasons. Robberg bladelets are argued to be inserts hafted into arrow shafts, but no such arguments are made for Howiesons Poort bladelets. Debates about projectile technology in the Howiesons Poort are centered on the retouched geometrics. However, even this one class of artifacts may represent functionally different tools based on size and multiple hafting arrangements have been proposed for them. I showed that the differences in small tool production between Howiesons Poort and Robberg technology highlight the need to be cautious with assumed associations between different classes of so-called “microlithic” technology and composite tools or projectile weaponry.

 

I have mentored 14 undergraduates through the Center for Experimental Archaeology at Davis (CEAD), more than 75% of whom were women or from minority groups. I have also co supervised four undergraduate Honors theses, all for students from nontraditional backgrounds through my experimental archaeology research program. I was able to provide an avenue for an Honors project for a disabled student who was concerned his wheelchair would prevent him from participating in archaeological research. Two of the Honors students I supervised have started Ph.D. programs at the University of Illinois Champaign-Urbana and the University of Nevada Reno, respectively. A third student is applying to Ph.D. programs for the 2024-2025 academic year. Results from this project will be incorporated into renovations of the Africa Hall and Ancient Egypt permanent exhibits at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, IL, which will reach millions of people annually.
